questions.text: A patient was presented with the exacerbated chronic lower back pain in the sacral region with irradiation to the back of the left leg, producing a strong pain throbbing and burning behind the knee. Pain was aggravated when bending forward or in reaching out position. In his history, he had a back condition from birth and later had an accident that resulted in fracture of the lumbar vertebrae. His MRI two months prior to this aggravation, showed degeneration of L1, disc degeneration, and protrusion of the disc at the S1 level. He was prescribed strong non-steroid pain medication that made him feel drowsy, but did not provide a full pain relief. Seeking resolution for his pain, he decided to try InterX therapy and treatment was aimed at whole Lumbosacral zone, dermatomes L1/L2 and L4, L5, S1-S3, left buttock, right buttock, left back of the knee. After two and a half weeks use, he reported no pain, no discomfort, he stopped taking pain medication and started with the core exercise program to stabilize the lumbar spine. Advice to limit driving, prolong sitting, rest, good nutrition, and gentle stretching exercises. Six months follow up confirmed that the patient still did not have pain, actively working and travelling. All of the following anatomical statements are true about this case except:

options.text: The location of sapheno-popliteal junction, into which the Short Saphenous Vein empties, is highly variable.

options.label: C
options.text: The Vein of Giacomini is the cranial extension of the Great Saphenous Vein.

options.label: D
options.text: Perforators allow blood flow from deep to superficial venous system.

questions.correct_answer: B. The location of sapheno-popliteal junction, into which the Short Saphenous Vein empties, is highly variable.
questions.explanation: Ans. B. The location of sapheno-popliteal junction, into which the short saphenous vein empties, is highly variable.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida comes for a prenatal care visit at 34 weeks’ gestation. Her abdomen is pictured below. She comments that her 36-year-old friend does not have these marks and wants to know why she does. Which of the following is not a strong risk factor associated with the development of striae gravidarum?

A patient is evaluated for hyponatremia and has the following laboratory studies: BUN – 10 mg/dl, Creatinine – 0.9 mg/dL, S. Osmolality – 254 mOsm/kg H 2 O, Na – 122 mEq/L, Urine studies: U. Osmolality – 460 mOsm/kg H 2 O, U. Na – 50 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hyponatremia?

Dr. Amrit Nasta is consulted regarding a 56-year-old patient, Alok, who has been diagnosed with metastatic melanoma. Alok's pathology report indicates a high expression of PD-L1 in tumor cells. After previously showing resistance to the BRAF inhibitor vemurafenib, Dr. Nasta decides to administer pembrolizumab, an immune checkpoint inhibitor, hoping to harness Alok's immune system against the tumor. A week into treatment with pembrolizumab, Alok presents with fatigue, joint pain, a mild rash, and an elevation of liver enzymes in his blood tests. What is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
Which of the following cell within cell phenomenon indicates live CD4+ T cells being captured by hepatocytes?

A patient presented with complaints of dysphagia. On UGI Endoscopy, a diagnosis of esophageal candidiasis was made. The organism obtained from the sample was cultured on a specialized media and the below finding were visible on microscopy of the culture. What phenomenon is shown below?

Dr. Rajesh, Medical Officer at a Primary Health Center (PHC) in a remote village of Maharashtra, encounters a case that prompts him to review the importance of timely immunizations. Mrs. Sharma, a 28-year-old mother, was brought up into the clinic holding her 18-month-old daughter, Riya, who has never received any vaccinations by ASHA. The family had been traveling frequently due to Mr. Sharma's job, and Riya's vaccinations got overlooked amidst the constant relocations. On inquiry, Dr. Rajesh learns that Riya has been generally healthy with no significant illnesses so far. Recognizing the importance of immediate intervention, Dr. Rajesh decides to initiate a catch-up vaccination schedule. Given Riya's age and her unvaccinated status, which combination of vaccines should Dr. Rajesh prioritize for this initial visit?

Four days after undergoing laparotomy for duodenal ulcer perforation, patient is started on clear liquids. He complains of epigastric discomfort and bilious vomiting. Abdominal examination reveals generalized distension without tenderness. All of these will be done next in management except:

options.label: A
options.text: Stop orals and insert NG tube

options.label: B
options.text: Stop orals and feed via NJ tube

questions.correct_answer: B. Stop orals and feed via NJ tube
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Stop orals and feed via NJ tube

questions.text: What is the composition of the membrane layers in this ultrasound image of twin pregnancy?
A 52-year-old man presents with a BP of 148/96 mm Hg and has a history of stroke. Routine Laboratory studies done were normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

Umesh, a 35-year-old male, presents to the outpatient department of Dr Mehta’s Hospitals, Chennai with intermittent fever, chills, and sweating for the past 10 days. He had recently returned from a 2-week trip to the Sundarbans, a forested region known for its endemicity with malaria. Laboratory investigations confirm the diagnosis of Plasmodium falciparum malaria, which is sensitive to chloroquine. Dr Dileep Kumar, the treating physician is planning to ensure a radical cure to prevent future relapses. Which of the following is the drug of choice for radical cure of malaria in this patient?

A 15-year-old girl presents with a midline neck swelling that moves on deglutition. USG revealed a 2 cm x 2 cm nodule on the left lobe of the thyroid, extending into the strap muscles. The histopathology image is given below. What of the following is not correct about this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased risk with RET/ PTC rearrangements and BRAF mutations

options.label: B
options.text: History of childhood radiation exposure with palpable lymph nodes as presentation

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of sheets of polygonal cells which stain positively with Congo red

options.label: D
options.text: Tumor cells have dispersed nuclear chromatin imparting it ground glass or optically clear appearance

questions.correct_answer: C. Presence of sheets of polygonal cells which stain positively with Congo red

questions.text: Biochemical analysis of pyogenic meningitis reveals all of the following, except:

options.label: B
options.text: Total leukocyte count: Highly elevated, neutrophilic

questions.text: Dr. Lakshmi Iyer, a renowned social economist from Chennai, is addressing a seminar on innovative measures for understanding country dynamics. She emphasized a particular index that evaluates the country based on multiple facets, rather than solely relying on income per capita. This index factors in aspects like deprivation in health, education, and living standards to provide a more comprehensive assessment. Which index is Dr. Iyer referring to?
Which of these intra-venous therapies is preferred while performing damage control resuscitation in traumatic hemorrhage?
After birth, these vessels seen on microscopy of an umbilical cord (marked by the black arrow) will become which of the following structures?
A 42-year-old man with HBV related cirrhosis has ascites requiring frequent LVP. All of the following are true regarding treatment of ascites EXCEPT:

options.label: D
options.text: TIPS has no survival benefit compared to LVP

questions.text: Dr. Sparsh Gupta is conducting a clinical study involving a 30-year-old participant named Kunal. They are examining a novel, pharmacologically inert substance called Y to study its elimination kinetics. Previous trials have shown that Y follows first order kinetics and has the plasma half-life of 1 hour. During the initial stage of the clinical trial, Kunal receives an intravenous administration of Y at a concentration of 20 mg/mL, infused at a constant rate of 2 mL/min for 12 hours. After ensuring that Y has been completely eliminated from Kunal's system, Dr. Gupta introduces changes to the protocol for a subsequent phase. The concentration of the solution is adjusted to 30 mg/mL, and the infusion rate is increased to 3 mL/min. Given the modifications to the infusion method, which among the following pharmacokinetic parameters related to Y is expected to change?

options.label: C
options.text: Time required to reach the steady-state concentration

questions.explanation: Ans. B. Steady state plasma concentration attained

questions.text: While attending a workshop on diagnostic testing, Dr. Ravi Sharma, an epidemiologist from Pune, explains the utility of a specific graph used to evaluate the performance of diagnostic tests. This graph helps clinicians and researchers understand the trade-off between the sensitivity and specificity of a test. Dr. Sharma further mentioned a specific area under this curve, which, when it equals 1, suggests the diagnostic test is perfect. Which of the following statements is true regarding the curve Dr. Sharma described?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a method for evaluating the quality/performance of tests.

options.label: B
options.text: It is plotted as test Sensitivity as x-coordinate versus its 1-Specificity (False positive rate FPR) as the y-coordinate.

options.label: C
options.text: A perfect test will lie towards the lower half of the curve area

options.label: D
options.text: A decrease in sensitivity results in a decrease in specificity.

questions.correct_answer: A. It is a method for evaluating the quality/performance of tests.
questions.explanation: Ans. A. It is a method for evaluating the quality/performance of tests.

questions.text: A 20-year-old primigravida presents to your office to start prenatal care. She reports having an ultrasound performed last week at another facility. She shows you an ultrasound image which is provided below. Interested in science, the patient would like to know what is happening to the fetus at this gestational age. Which of the following statements would be incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: The fetus has fingers and toes

options.label: C
options.text: The eyes are moving, and there is blinking

options.label: D
options.text: The fetus is beginning to make spontaneous movements

questions.correct_answer: C. The eyes are moving, and there is blinking
questions.explanation: Ans. C. The eyes are moving, and there is blinking

questions.text: You are receiving a patient with headache in the emergency. CT scan is shown below. Patient’s Serum Sodium is 126 mEq/L. Which of the following treatment is inappropriate?

Dr. Apurv Mehra is managing a 45-year-old patient named Rakesh, who presents with recurring episodes of joint pain and inflammation. After a thorough assessment, Dr. Mehra diagnoses him with hyperuricemia predisposing to gout. To better understand the patient's uric acid metabolism, the doctor decides to measure the total amount of uric acid. After receiving the baseline measurements, Rakesh is prescribed an "antigout" medication. Several weeks into the therapy, Dr. Mehra repeats the 24-hour urine uric acid measurement to evaluate the drug's effectiveness. He observes a significant reduction in the urate content in the post-treatment sample. Throughout the treatment period, Rakesh confirms no new health concerns, and he assures Dr. Mehra that his daily proteins and purine intake remains unchanged. Given these observations, which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed to Rakesh?

In a bid to improve the adherence to Tuberculosis (TB) treatment, a new technological initiative has been introduced in certain TB control programs. Dr. Kavita Mehta, a public health expert in Mumbai, elucidated this method during a seminar on innovative solutions for enhancing TB treatment outcomes. According to her presentation, the anti-TB blister packs come with a unique feature to ensure patient compliance. How does this system function to ensure that patients have taken their daily medication?

options.label: A
options.text: The blister pack has a QR code that patients scan after medication intake, confirming dose administration.

options.label: B
options.text: Each blister pack has a hidden phone number that becomes visible only when a dose is dispensed. Patients are then required to call this number as a sign of having taken the dose.

options.label: C
options.text: The blister pack contains a small chip that sends automated reminders to patients about medication timings.

options.label: D
options.text: Patients have to send a photograph of the consumed medication to a centralized system for dose verification.

questions.correct_answer: B. Each blister pack has a hidden phone number that becomes visible only when a dose is dispensed. Patients are then required to call this number as a sign of having taken the dose.
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Each blister pack has a hidden phone number that becomes visible only when a dose is dispensed. Patients are then required to call this number as a sign of having taken the dose.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman with phenylketonuria wants to know what the best way is to prevent damage to a fetus when she gets pregnant.

options.label: A
options.text: Use a donor egg to get pregnant

options.label: B
options.text: Make sure her phenylalanine levels are normal 3 months prior to conception

options.label: C
options.text: Adhere to a phenylalanine-restricted diet once she has a positive pregnancy test

options.label: D
options.text: Undergo chorionic villus sampling in the first trimester to determine if the fetus inherited the defect

questions.correct_answer: B. Make sure her phenylalanine levels are normal 3 months prior to conception
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Make sure her phenylalanine levels are normal 3 months prior to conception

questions.text: You are reviewing a serology report of a patient in a routine MHC: HBSAg – Negative, Anti HBS – Negative, Anti HBC – Positive, HBEAg – Negative, Anti HBE – Negative. All of the following are true except?

Dr. Vivek Jain is reviewing medications at a community health camp. One of his tasks is to counsel on the effective use of glipizide for managing elevated blood sugar levels. Among the attendees, there's a diverse group of patients with various health profiles. Dr. Jain recognizes that glipizide can reduce blood sugar in many patient groups, but there's one category of individuals in which it might not have a notable effect. Which of the following patients is LEAST likely to experience a significant reduction in blood sugar levels with glipizide?

options.label: B
options.text: A 45-year-old obese person with type 2 diabetes mellitus

options.label: C
options.text: A 50-year-old woman with Polycystic Ovary Disease and impaired glucose tolerance

questions.correct_answer: D. A 65-year-old man with type 1 diabetes

questions.text: During a clinical case discussion, Dr. Lakshmi Narayan, PG 1st year student, presented a case of a 14-year-old boy. The patient presented with sudden onset high fever, severe abdominal pain, and signs of circulatory failure. Further laboratory investigations showed thrombocytopenia, increased hematocrit levels, and evidence of plasma leakage. The boy was diagnosed with Dengue Shock Syndrome (DSS). Dr. Narayan emphasized the importance of recognizing the clinical and laboratory features to distinguish DSS from other febrile illnesses. Which of the following is NOT a characteristic feature of Dengue Shock Syndrome?

A 30-year-old G3P1 presents at 18 weeks’ gestation for counseling regarding an increased risk for trisomy 21 on quadruple marker maternal serum screen. A targeted fetal anatomical survey shows no abnormalities. She understands the fetus may still have trisomy 21. What should she do next?

options.label: D
options.text: Nothing – It is likely a false-positive result

questions.text: An obese 23-year-old woman presents to the neurology clinic with 3 days of a dull headache that worsens when she lies flat. She is a known case of history of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML), for which she is being treated with ATRA (Al-Trans-Retinoic Acid). She has no neck rigidity or fever. This patient is most likely experiencing which of the following?

During your rural posting after the internship, you encounter a patient of acute cardiac failure. Your preferred drug for this condition is dobutamine. However, it is not available there. Which of the following other drugs, or combination of drugs, would be a suitable alternative, giving the pharmacologic equivalent of what you want the dobutamine to do?

At an epidemiology conference in Toronto, Dr. Arjun Singh, an esteemed epidemiologist, showcased a compelling longitudinal study. In his study, 45,000 men were diligently monitored over 25 years, of which 2,500 developed prostate cancer. In an attempt to enhance the depth of the study, an additional 3,500 men confirmed to be healthy were included as controls. Dr. Singh highlighted that at the start of the study, potential risk factors were deduced from baseline data gathered through questionnaires disseminated to both sets of participants along with their blood samples which were stored after proper labelling. This strategic approach was designed to trace the onset of disease over an extended period, subsequently analysing it with the baseline data. Which terminology best describes this study design?
Among women who become pregnant while using contraception, the relative number of ectopic pregnancies is increased with which of the following contraceptives?

ACEi/ARBs are considered to be the best choices for reducing the progression to End stage renal disease in patients with Diabetic Kidney disease. What is the newer drug that has shown promise in reducing albuminuria and progression to End stage renal disease?
Which of the following drug is the only medication useful in preventing disability progression in a patient with primary progressive multiple sclerosis?

A 26-year-old G3P3 is postpartum day 1 following an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. She reports sharp, intermittent lower abdominal pain, which is more severe than in her prior deliveries. Her heart rate is 84 beats per minute, blood pressure 110/60 mmHg, and her temperature 99.3°F. Her abdomen is soft on examination and there is no uterine tenderness. A scant amount of lochia is appreciated on a speculum examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following statements is false regarding kidney transplantation?

options.label: A
options.text: Kidney transplantation and maintenance dialysis have same overall survival and mortality rates

options.label: B
options.text: One-year mortality after Kidney Transplantation is less than those patients who are on the wait list

options.label: C
options.text: The transplantation is cost effective from the second year after transplantation

options.label: D
options.text: Waiting time on dialysis is one of the strongest independent modifiable risk factor for transplant outcomes

questions.correct_answer: A. Kidney transplantation and maintenance dialysis have same overall survival and mortality rates
questions.explanation: Ans. A. Kidney transplantation and maintenance dialysis have small overall survival and mortality rates

questions.text: Dr. Ayesha Gupta, an emergency medicine specialist, is conducting a training session for first responders on mass casualty incidents. She emphasizes the importance of a specific triage system that rapidly assesses victims based on their ability to walk, respiratory status, perfusion, and mental function. This system prioritizes patients based on the severity of their injuries to ensure that those who are most likely to survive with immediate treatment are attended to first, which is known as START Triage. What is the correct full form of START ?
questions.correct_answer: C. Simple Triage and Rapid Treatment
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Simple Triage and Rapid Treatment
